attributes.title: Weight of gaur (Bos gaurus) and banteng (Bos javanicus) killed by tigers in Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary, Thailand, are critical for estimating tiger diet

summary.value: The primary prey of tigers across much of Southeast Asia has been depleted, reducing the ability of already limited habitat to support tigers. To better understand the extent to which the tiger’s two largest prey species, gaur (Bos gaurus) and banteng (Bos javanicus), contribute to the tiger’s diet, we estimated the average size of these species killed by tigers. This information is needed to correctly estimate biomass of these species in tiger diet and to devise strategies to increase tiger carrying capacity where habitat is fragmented and limited in west-central Thailand. We used temporally clumped locations of 24 satellite radio-collared tigers to identify their kill sites and obtained mandibles from 82 gaur and 79 banteng. Kills were aged by teeth eruption sequence, sectioning the M1 molar and counting cementum annuli. Of all gaur killed, 45.2% were adults; of all banteng killed 55.7% were adults.  The smaller proportion of large gaur killed by tigers may be due to size difference of these species.  The average weight of banteng killed was 423.9 kg, which was similar to the 397.9 kg average weight for gaur. The mean weight of both prey species is 3.5 to 4.5 times greater than the predicted 1:1 prey to predator ratio. In the absence of medium-sized prey, killing these larger animals may be especially critical for female tigers when provisioning nearly independent young when male offspring are already larger than the mother. This is the first study to present data on the average weights of gaur and banteng killed in Southeast Asia and these results suggest that these are key prey species to target in tiger prey recovery efforts

registration_responses.summary: The primary prey of tigers across much of Southeast Asia has been depleted, reducing the ability of already limited habitat to support tigers. To better understand the extent to which the tiger’s two largest prey species, gaur (Bos gaurus) and banteng (Bos javanicus), contribute to the tiger’s diet, we estimated the average size of these species killed by tigers. This information is needed to correctly estimate biomass of these species in tiger diet and to devise strategies to increase tiger carrying capacity where habitat is fragmented and limited in west-central Thailand. We used temporally clumped locations of 24 satellite radio-collared tigers to identify their kill sites and obtained mandibles from 82 gaur and 79 banteng. Kills were aged by teeth eruption sequence, sectioning the M1 molar and counting cementum annuli. Of all gaur killed, 45.2% were adults; of all banteng killed 55.7% were adults.  The smaller proportion of large gaur killed by tigers may be due to size difference of these species.  The average weight of banteng killed was 423.9 kg, which was similar to the 397.9 kg average weight for gaur. The mean weight of both prey species is 3.5 to 4.5 times greater than the predicted 1:1 prey to predator ratio. In the absence of medium-sized prey, killing these larger animals may be especially critical for female tigers when provisioning nearly independent young when male offspring are already larger than the mother. This is the first study to present data on the average weights of gaur and banteng killed in Southeast Asia and these results suggest that these are key prey species to target in tiger prey recovery efforts

attributes.title: Disentangling Effect Sizes and Inferential Statistics in Science Communication

summary.value: Preregistration of the project - see the form ("Preregistration Form.pdf")

registration_responses.summary: Preregistration of the project - see the form ("Preregistration Form.pdf")

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

analyses.value:
4 x 1 Anova: (feeling bad, no satisfaction), (feeling good, satisfaction), (feeling bad, satisfaction), (feeling good, no satisfaction). The data on the reversed order will be collapsed for the main Anova.

Additional analses look at the effect of the reversed order, as well as posthoc tests on the pairwise comparisons between the various conditions.

We will also conduct one-sample t-tests to investigate whether the average ratings for the main conditions are above / below the midline of 4.

We conduct a t-test to investigate whether significantly more participants fail the satisfaction question compared to the feeling good question in the mixed designs.

We conduct a mediation analysis to test for the influence of the happiness rating on the failed additional questions.

We conduct t-tests investigating the effect of asking the additional questions first.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded who indicate that their mother tongue is not English, as well as those participants who fail to answer all main questions.

dependent.value: The main dependent variable is rated happiness. The question asked is "Do you think that John was happy during the course of the four years?" People's answer will be measured on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from Not at all, in Between, to Absolutely.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of eight conditions. Two baseline conditions (both feeling good and satisfaction) & (feeling bad, no satisfaction). Two conditions for (feeling good, no satisfaction) in which the order between the respective information is reversed. Two conditions for (feeling bad, satisfaction) in which the order between the respective information is reversed. And two conditions (feeling good, no satisfaction) & (feeling bad, satisfaction)  in which the additional questions are asked before the test question (happiness question) to investigate the effect of the extra questions.

hypothesis.value:
The main question is whether satisfaction theories or hedonism can better predict people's happiness ratings.

In a series of vignettes, we ask people to rate whether the protagonist of the story is happy. In the vignettes, we provide information about whether the protagonist is (dis-)satisfied with his life and whether the protagonist feels good / bad most of the days.

Our main hypothesis is that when a person is described to feel good most of the time, on average people will rate that person happy, regardless of whether she is satisfied with her life or not. When a person is described to feel bad most of the time, on average people will rate that person unhappy, regardless of whether she is satisfied with her life or not.

We will also ask two additional questions after the test question about happiness. The first asks whether people believe the protagonist to be satisfied (satisfaction question) . The second asks whether people believe the protagonist to feel good most of the time (feeling good question). We hypothesize that significantly more people will wrongly answer the satisfaction question compared to the feeling good question. We will also carry out a meditation analysis to investigate whether such a finding is mediated by people's answer to the main question (happiness question).

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

We will also conduct one-sample t-tests to investigate whether the average ratings for the main conditions are above / below the midline of 4.

We conduct a t-test to investigate whether significantly more participants fail the satisfaction question compared to the feeling good question in the mixed designs.

We conduct a mediation analysis to test for the influence of the happiness rating on the failed additional questions.

We conduct t-tests investigating the effect of asking the additional questions first.

Two conditions for (feeling bad, satisfaction) in which the order between the respective information is reversed. And two conditions (feeling good, no satisfaction) & (feeling bad, satisfaction)  in which the additional questions are asked before the test question (happiness question) to investigate the effect of the extra questions.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The main question is whether satisfaction theories or hedonism can better predict people's happiness ratings.

In a series of vignettes, we ask people to rate whether the protagonist of the story is happy. In the vignettes, we provide information about whether the protagonist is (dis-)satisfied with his life and whether the protagonist feels good / bad most of the days.

attributes.title: Comparing the Effects of Social and Monetary Feedback on Habit Breaking Among Individuals Experiencing Depressive Symptoms

q1.value: Comparing the Effects of Social and Monetary Feedback on Habit Breaking Among Individuals Experiencing Depressive Symptoms

q2.value: Kaileigh Byrne, hunter willis, Stephanie Six

q3.value: Humans are known for being creatures of habit; forming habits helps people find stability and comfort in the hustle of everyday life. Previous research indicates that monetary feedback appeals more to both individuals with and without depressive symptoms than social feedback in terms of forming habits. However, the relationship between depressive symptoms and habit breaking remains an under-explored area of research. This study will investigate (1) whether social or monetary feedback leads to faster habit breaking and (2) whether depressive symptoms, social anhedonia, and/or loneliness influence this relationship. A two-stage reinforcement learning devaluation task will be used to investigate responses to social and monetary feedback. It is predicted that monetary feedback will be more incentivizing across all individuals thus lead to slower devaluation compared to social feedback. Furthermore, individuals experiencing higher levels of depressive symptoms may exhibit higher devaluation scores, indicative of better habit breaking, under social feedback compared to monetary feedback.

q4.value:
It is predicted that monetary feedback will be associated with increased difficulty breaking habits compared to the social feedback condition across all individuals. In previous studies, it has been shown that individuals with low levels or no depressive symptoms formed habits more quickly when monetary feedback, rewards, or incentives were offered, thus leading to the assumptions that a quicker habit formation means a slower, more difficult devaluation process (Ethridge et al., 2017).

 Secondly, research shows that individuals with depression are less responsive to positive social rewards (Smoski et al., 2013; Xie et al., 2014). In line with this work, it is hypothesized that individuals experiencing higher levels of depressive symptoms and/or higher levels of social anhedonia symptoms may exhibit higher devaluation scores, indicative of better habit breaking, under social feedback compared to monetary feedback.  Finally, we predict that spontaneous eyeblink rate, an indirect proxy for striatal dopamine, may moderate the relationship between depressive symptoms and devaluation sensitivity.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: This study will entail a mixed design.  The categorical, between-subjects variable is the feedback condition: monetary feedback vs. social feedback.  The continuous, within-subjects variable are spontaneous eyeblink rate, CES-D depressive symptoms, Chapman Social Anhedonia Scores, and UCLA Loneliness scores. The primary outcome measure is devaluation sensitivity, which is an index of effective habit breaking tendencies.

q9.value: We will use block randomization in which everyone that comes in for a given timeslot will be randomly assigned into either the monetary or social feedback condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: At least 120 undergraduates (n = 60 per monetary vs. social feedback condition) from Clemson University will participate in this study. Participants will be recruited through the Clemson SONA system.  All of those involved will be 18 years or older. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two feedback conditions. Participants will be given course credit for participating.  Those in the monetary condition may be earn up to $10 as bonus based on their performance.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 160 participants.  We will attempt to recruit up to 200 participants to account for participant outliers in eyeblink rate analysis and poor responders on the task.  We will exclude those that miss 20 - 25% or more of trials from data analysis.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power 3.1 to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .20 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. With condition, eyeblink rate, CESD scores, social anhedonia scores, and loneliness as predictors, we would need a sample size of 70 to reach 80% power.

q15.value: We will plan to collect data for 14 weeks.  We will stop data collection at the end of that 14 week period.

question.value: We will manipulate whether participants are exposed to the social or monetary feedback condition.

The outcome measure is devaluation sensitivity on a two-choice reinforcement learning task (Gillan et al., 2015; Byrne et al., 2019). 

We will also examine accuracy on the learning phase of the task.

Devaluation sensitivity will be computed as the number of valued trials that participants responded on minus the number of devalued trials that participants responded on. Higher values indicate enhanced devaluation sensitivity.

To evaluate our hypotheses regarding whether the individual difference variables (EBR, CES-D depressive symptoms, social anhedonia, and lonelineness) would predict performance measures from the task (devaluation sensitivity, model-based index, and model-free index), correlations will be computed among these variables. 

Next, to assess relationships between these predictors and devaluation sensitivity, we will perform regression analyses that (1) test the prediction that monetary feedback would negatively predict devaluation sensitivity and model-based learning, and (2) investigated the possibility that the predictors would interact with EBR to influence devaluation sensitivity and model-based strategies.

Supplemental mixed-effects logistic regression analyses were performed using the lme4 modules of the R statistical package may also be used to examine reinforcement learning phase model-based and model-free behavior.

q20.value: See Byrne, K. A., Otto, A. R., Pang, B., Patrick, C. J., & Worthy, D. A. (2019). Substance use is associated with reduced devaluation sensitivity. Cognitive, Affective, & Behavioral Neuroscience, 19(1), 40-55 for details on analyzing the two-stage reinforcement learning task.  We will follow this same procedure in the planned study.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria.

q22.value: We will exclude participants' whose EBR data is 2.5 standard deviations above or below the mean or who have dry eye or other conditions that may affect EBR.  We will also exclude participants who do not respond on more than 20 - 25% of reinforcement learning phase trials.

q23.value: participants with missing data for any parts of the study will be excluded from analyses.

attributes.title: Metacognition of the outsourced mind: Default

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will collect data from 300 participants via MTurk, deviations from this number are due to the MTurk software and outside of our control.

analyses.value: A linear regression using condition to predict participants' accuracy and future performance ratings with planned comparisons (independent samples t-tests) between conditions.

outliers.value: Participants who fail at least 1 of the 2 initial attention check questions or click away from the survey during the quiz portion for more than 15 second will be excluded.

dependent.value: If you were to answer another set of similar questions without any outside help or hints, what percentage would you answer correctly?  (0–100)

conditions.value: 3 (Button Help vs. Default Help vs. No Help)

hypothesis.value: Does a hint being shown by default (vs. requiring pressing a button to view) to answer trivia question affect accuracy and predictions of future performance?

attributes.title: A Systematic Scoping Study of Child Marriage Research from 2000 to 2020

summary.value:
Objective: The purpose of this review is to provide a systematic summary of the complete body of child marriage evidence from 2000 to 2020, in an effort to contribute to the strengthening and coordination of research efforts and collective learning in the child marriage field. 

Methods: Studies will identified by (1) database searches in PubMed, PsycINFO, Embase, Cinahl Plus, Popline, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Library, (2) targeted hand-searches of fifteen key organizations known to be involved in child marriage prevention, (3) reference list reviews and (4) consultations with relevant experts.


Inclusion Criteria: Focus on child, early, or forced marriage, or married adolescents; Published between 2000 and 2020, Published in English, French, Spanish, and Portuguese; Peer-reviewed research articles, dissertations, reports, commentaries, protocols, toolkits and evidence-generating briefs.

Originality/Value: Given the large and rapidly growing evidence base on child marriage, it is important to take stock of what is and is not being addressed. To date there has been no exhaustive review of child marriage research globally over the span of twenty years. This review will assess where progress has been made in child marriage research, and where the gaps lie to inform research and programmatic priorities.

registration_responses.summary:
Objective: The purpose of this review is to provide a systematic summary of the complete body of child marriage evidence from 2000 to 2020, in an effort to contribute to the strengthening and coordination of research efforts and collective learning in the child marriage field. 

Methods: Studies will identified by (1) database searches in PubMed, PsycINFO, Embase, Cinahl Plus, Popline, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Library, (2) targeted hand-searches of fifteen key organizations known to be involved in child marriage prevention, (3) reference list reviews and (4) consultations with relevant experts.


Inclusion Criteria: Focus on child, early, or forced marriage, or married adolescents; Published between 2000 and 2020, Published in English, French, Spanish, and Portuguese; Peer-reviewed research articles, dissertations, reports, commentaries, protocols, toolkits and evidence-generating briefs.

Originality/Value: Given the large and rapidly growing evidence base on child marriage, it is important to take stock of what is and is not being addressed. To date there has been no exhaustive review of child marriage research globally over the span of twenty years. This review will assess where progress has been made in child marriage research, and where the gaps lie to inform research and programmatic priorities.

attributes.title: Possible differential effects of fatigue on persuasion when argument's fatigue relevance is manipulated
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: I plan to start data analysis upon pre-registration.

dataCollectionDates.value: Data was collected online in April of 2019.

question2a.value:
1. Argument quality (weak vs. strong argument)
a. Between-participant
b. orthogonal

2. Fatigue relevance of the message (low vs. high)
a. Between-participant
b. orthogonal

3. Fatigue (non-manipulated continuous, measured predictor variable; measured with 4 items [fatigued, tired, sleepy, drowsy] embedded in a distractor list)
a. between-participant
b. orthogonal

question2b.value:
1. Message evaluation/persuasion (5 9-point semantic differentials from Petty et al., 1977)

2. State empathy toward message source (11 items from 12-item Shen empathy scale (2010); 7-point responses from "Not at all" to "Completely" - 1 item left out due to clerical error ("I can understand what the character was going through in the message")

3. Message involvement (10 items from the Personal Involvement Inventory [Zaichkowsky, 1994])

question3b.value:
1. Manipulation check - participant rating of argument quality - this should differ between the strong and weak argument conditions

2. Manipulation check - participant rating of how difficult the argument was to understand, how hard it was to follow, and the extent to which it had a complex structure. These should not differ between the strong and weak argument conditions, and if they do, they should be controlled for. 

3. Current mood (3 items, 7-point response from "very bad-very good," "very sad - very happy," and "very unpleasant - very pleasant." 

4. Need for Cognition (Petty, Cacioppo & Kao's [1984] version) will be used as a covariate since the measure relates to persuasion. 

5. Trait empathy (Davis' [1980) Interpersonal Reactivity Index). This will be used as a covariate to control for individual differences in general ability/tendency to empathize with others.

question10b.value:
Participants were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: strong, fatigue-relevant argument, strong, fatigue-irrelevant argument, weak, fatigue-relevant argument, and weak, fatigue-irrelevant argument. All participants first read a persuasive message. In the fatigue-relevant condition, participants were instructed to read an email from an overtired employee named George asking his boss explaining why he missed a project deadline and requesting an extension. In the fatigue-irrelevant condition, participants were instructed to read a communication regarding a new comprehensive exam policy at a large state university in the U.S.. The fatigue-relevant weak and strong arguments had been piloted for argument quality in prior work. The fatigue-irrelevant arguments were adapted to match the length of the other arguments in the study from Luttrell et al., 2017.

Following this, all participants completed the primary dependent measures of persuasion, empathy and involvement. The question order for each of the following sections was randomized. The persuasion measure consisted of five 9-point semantic differentials assessing participants' evaluation of the message (example: "To what extent do you think the communication made its point effectively?" from "not at all" to "completely;" from Petty et al., 1977). They then completed 11 items from the 12-item Shen (2010) empathy scale using seven response options (example: "I experienced the same emotions as the writer did when reading the article" from "Not at all" to "completely"). The items used George as a referent in the fatigue-relevant condition and 'the writer' as a referent in the fatigue-irrelevant condition. Participant involvement in the message was assessed with the 10-item Personal Involvement Inventory (Zaichkowsky, 1994) with the referent adapted depending on the fatigue relevance condition. While all participants responded to the 10 items using 7-point semantic differentials (e.g., "To me, X is unimportant-important, boring-interesting, etc."), the referent (X) was "George's emailed request" for those in the fatigue-relevant condition and "the article" in the fatigue-irrelevant condition. 

Following the main dependent measures, participants responded to manipulation checks on the argument quality manipulation. The first of these four items assessed their rating of the quality of the arguments using 11 options from "Not very good arguments" to "Very good arguments." The other three manipulation checks measured the difficulty of the arguments, how hard they were to follow, and the extent to which they had a complex structure, each on an 8-point response scale from "Not at all" to "Extremely."

In the next section of the survey, participants indicated the extent to which a series of 24 terms  applied to them at that moment. Most of these terms were distractor items, but seven items related to current fatigue: fatigued, tired, sleepy, drowsy, energetic, aware, and awake. 

The next question was an attention check in which participants were instructed not to respond with their favorite color but with "white", with the question itself asking what their favorite color was. 

Participants then completed the 18-item Need for Cognition scale (Petty, Cacioppo & Kao, 1984) and the 28-item Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davis, 1980). They provided their gender, age, and ethnicity, reported how seriously they took the study using five response options from "I honestly blew through the questions and did not pay attention to the instructions" to "I took my time and answered thoughtfully." They were given a text box to enter any comments regarding typos or unclear instructions and read debriefing information.

question4b.value: These data have already been collected in April 2019.

question5b.value: All participants were recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk and completed the experiment on SurveyMonkey. They were paid $1.25 for 15 minutes of their time.

question6b.value: While a formal power analysis was not conducted, prior studies I've run in this area suggested that a sample size of 125 would be sufficient to pick up on a small effect size with a power criterion of 80%, given two conditions and five covariates. With this more complicated, 4-condition study, I was limited by budget concerns to collecting only 100 participants per each of the 4 conditions, so the sample size very likely is too small for 80% power.

question7b.value: Budget constraints limited me to collecting 100 participants per each of the 4 conditions.

question8b.value:
I incorporated an attention-check question which will be used to exclude inattentive participants (or programs which aren't participants at all).

Toward the end of the study, participants also self-report their attention levels. Those who self-report that they "honestly blew through the questions and did not pay attention to the instructions" will be excluded. 

The dataset will also be inspected, and if it is obvious that an individual did not pay attention (that is, selected the same response for the entire study), they will be excluded. Edge cases (maybe they were attentive, maybe not) will be kept in the dataset.

question9b.value: The data has already been collected.

question6c.value: I plan to use Benjamini & Hochberg's (2000) adaptive procedure to control the false discovery rate across the three ANCOVAs while keeping power as high as possible.

question7c.value:
In cases where participants do not complete an entire scale, that variable will not be included for that individual, meaning that if that variable is included in an analysis, that participant will not be included. 

If the participant completes the majority of questions in a given scale, their average on the completed questions will stand for their composite score.

question8c.value:
For all previously-validated scales, all items will be included. 

For the current fatigue measure, since I have used only the four fatigue-sleepy-tired-drowsy items in past work, I will do so again here.

question9c.value: None other than averaging for composite scores.

question1a.value:
1. Message evaluation: I expect an argument quality x current fatigue x message relevance interaction predicting message evaluation (persuasion).

2. State empathy: I expect a current fatigue x message relevance interaction predicting state empathy. This might also interact with argument quality (that is, perhaps it will be easier to empathize with weak arguments vs. strong, or vice versa - this an exploratory prediction). 

3. Message involvement: I expect a current fatigue x message relevance interaction predicting message involvement. This might also interact with argument quality.

question2a.value:
1. Message evaluation (persuasion): 
a. Specifically, I expect that in the weak argument condition, fatigue will lead to more persuasion, but only if the message is fatigue-relevant. If the message is fatigue-irrelevant, fatigue will lead to less persuasion. 
b. In the strong argument condition, fatigue will lead to more persuasion if the message is fatigue-relevant; fatigue will also lead to more persuasion if the message is fatigue-irrelevant.

2. State empathy: 
a. Here, I expect that in the weak argument condition, fatigue will lead to more state empathy when the arguments are fatigue-relevant, but will have no impact on empathy when the arguments are fatigue-irrelevant. 
b. In the strong argument condition, I expect that fatigue will lead to more state empathy when the arguments are fatigue-relevant, but will have no impact on empathy when the arguments are fatigue-irrelevant. 

3. Message involvement: 
a. I expect that in the weak argument condition, fatigue will lead to more message involvement, but only if the arguments are fatigue-relevant. If the arguments are fatigue-irrelevant, fatigue should lead to less message involvement. 
b. In the strong argument condition, fatigue should lead to more message involvement when the arguments are fatigue-relevant, but less involvement if the arguments are fatigue-irrelevant.

question3a.value:
Manipulated variables:

1. Argument quality. The main manipulation check for this is a single item "How would you rate the quality of the arguments" on an 11-point scale from "Not very good" to "Very good." The strong-argument condition should score higher on this than the weak-argument condition.

2. Message fatigue relevance - This was manipulated by either presenting an argument from a fatigued individual regarding a work extension or an argument related to instituting comprehensive exams in the future at a university. A manipulation check was not included because the separate arguments seemed to the researcher to differ fairly obviously in terms of fatigue relevance, but it was also not considered as necessary (it might be helpful to include in the future)

question5a.value:
How might experiencing the same visceral state as a persuasive source impact persuasion? Research on the ELM (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986) suggests the visceral state could either distract from the message or increase message involvement. Distraction disrupts thoughts in response to a message, reducing argument quality effects and resulting in fewer favorable (unfavorable) thoughts if the message is strong (weak; Petty, Wells, & Brock, 1976; Lammers & Becker, 1980). Involvement tends to increase argument quality effects by enhancing message scrutiny (e.g., Petty & Cacioppo, 1990; Ajzen, Brown & Rosenthal, 1996; Petty & Cacioppo, 1984; Petty, Cacioppo & Schumann, 1983; Peck & Wiggins Johnson, 2011; Oreg & Sverdlik, 2014). 

A third possibility relates to a phenomenon known as the hot-cold empathy gap. This gap occurs between people in a visceral (hot) versus neutral (cold) state. Those currently in hot states (e.g., hungry, tired, etc.) better appreciate the impact of past or future hot states on themselves or others whereas those in cold states tend to underestimate the impact of hot states (Loewenstein, 1996, 2005). Empathy gaps have been demonstrated in contexts such as social pain (Nordgren, Banas, & MacDonald, 2011), torture evaluations (Nordgren, McDonnell, & Loewenstein, 2011), cigarette cravings (Sayette, Loewenstein, Griffin, & Blankenship, 2008), and public speaking fear (Van Boven, Loewenstein, & Dunning, 2005). 

For example, Nordgren, van der Pligt, and van Harreveld (2007) manipulated participant fatigue by having some complete a difficult and others a mild memory task. Everyone read a vignette describing an overtired woman who used racial slurs in a confrontation with a cashier. Consistent with other empathy gap research, fatigued participants felt more similar to the woman, had more compassion for her, and evaluated her more positively than non-fatigued participants. 

If being in the same visceral state as someone else increases empathy, how might empathy impact persuasion? Some research suggests that empathy increases message involvement, leading to more persuasion (Skumanich & Kintsfather, 1996; Polyorat, Alden, & Kim, 2007; Bae, 2008); however, this finding has not been tested when persuasive messages are weak. Thus, whether empathy would increase or decrease acceptance of weak arguments is unknown. Nordgren et al.’s (2007) vignette, though, appears analogous to a weak argument; the woman who made a racist remark while fatigued was “rarely [rated] beyond the midpoint of the scale and [was] thus not overtly favorable” (p. 82). That empathy toward such an unfavorable target led to increased similarity and evaluations suggests that the same could happen for persuasion.

question6a.value:
The account I have put forward is an empathy-gap account of persuasion, but there are two alternative possibilities. The empathy account is listed first, followed by a distraction account and a relevance/involvement account.

1. Hot-cold empathy gap account (e.g., Nordgren, van der Pligt, and van Harreveld, 2007; Loewenstein, 2005): If fatigue leads to a match between the visceral states of participants and the message source, then fatigued participants should be more persuaded by a fatigue-relevant message (and empathize more with its source & be more involved with the message), regardless of argument quality. When the message is not fatigue-relevant, though, fatigue should not impact empathy, and should instead distract participants, reducing message involvement and leading to more persuasion when the argument is weak and less persuasion when the argument is strong.

1. Distraction account (e.g., Petty, Wells & Brock, 1976): If fatigue only ever leads to distraction, I would expect message fatigue relevance not to moderate the interaction between argument quality and fatigue in predicting persuasion. Fatigued participants would always find the weak (strong) arguments more (less) persuasive than non-fatigued participants. I wouldn't expect empathy to be impacted by fatigue, and I would expect fatigue to relate to a decrease in message involvement regardless of argument quality or fatigue relevance.

2. Relevance/involvement account (e.g., Petty, Cacioppo, & Schumann, 1983): If fatigued participants find the fatigue-relevant message more personally relevant than non-fatigued participants, I would expect argument quality effects to be larger (weak arguments less persuasive, strong arguments more persuasive) for fatigued than non-fatigued participants - but only when the message is fatigue-relevant (not fatigue-irrelevant). If the message is fatigue-irrelevant, fatigue should distract participants, leading to smaller argument-quality effects for fatigued than non-fatigued participants. I have no predictions for empathy from this account, but I do predict that message involvement will increase among fatigued participants (vs. less-fatigued participants) when arguments are fatigue-relevant, regardless of argument quality, and potentially decrease when arguments are not fatigue-relevant.

question1c.value:
Predictor variables:

Argument quality condition will be coded as weak = -1 and strong = +1. 

Current fatigue will be assessed with four of the seven current fatigue terms (fatigued, tired, sleepy, drowsy). Previous work with this measure has suggested that these four tend to have the highest internal consistency. The internal consistency will be assessed using Cronbach's alpha, and given sufficient reliability they will be averaged together to create a current fatigue composite score. 

Fatigue relevance of the message will be coded as -1 = fatigue irrelevant and +1 = fatigue relevant. 

Outcome variables:

Persuasion: The internal consistency of the five message-evaluation items will be assessed using Cronbach's alpha. Given sufficient reliability, they will be averaged together to create a persuasion composite score. 

Covariates: If the manipulation checks on argument difficulty, how hard it was to follow, and the complexity of its structure fail (i.e., they differ between the strong and weak argument conditions), the relevant manipulation checks will be controlled for in the analysis. The three current mood items will be checked for reliability using Cronbach's alpha and averaged together to create a current mood composite. The same reliability check + compositing process will be completed for Need for Cognition (18 items) and Trait Empathy (using the 26 items from Davis' Interpersonal Reactivity Index). Gender will be coded as -1 = male, 0 = non-binary, and +1 = female. Age will be used as a quantitative continuous variable.

question2c.value:
A between-subjects ANCOVA will be conducted predicting persuasion from argument quality (1 = strong, -1 = weak), current fatigue, fatigue relevance (-1 = irrelevant, 1 = relevant), and all interactions controlling for current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks that failed. 95% confidence intervals and effect sizes (partial eta-squared) for regression coefficients will also be calculated. 

The analysis will be run a second time without the covariates.

If the predicted argument quality x current fatigue x message relevance interaction predicting persuasion is significant (or close to), the following simple effects analyses will be conducted:

1. A simple 2-way argument quality x current fatigue interaction when the message is fatigue relevant - I predict no interaction, but that persuasion will increase as current fatigue increases regardless of argument quality. 

2. A simple 2-way argument quality x current fatigue interaction when the message is not fatigue relevant - I predict an interaction such that participants higher in fatigue will display a smaller argument quality effect than participants lower in fatigue. 

If significant, the simple effect of current fatigue when arguments are weak will be tested as well as the simple effect of current fatigue when arguments are strong.

question3c.value:
Argument quality and fatigue relevance are true, manipulated IVs.

Current fatigue is a non-manipulated, continuous predictor variable. 

Fatigue relevance is seen as a moderator of the interaction between argument quality and current fatigue (in which current fatigue moderates argument quality effects). 

Persuasion is the primary dependent measure. 

Current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks re: argument difficulty that fail are covariates.

question4c.value:
Current mood - since mood can impact persuasion (see Bless et al., 1990), it will be controlled for. 

Age - this is admittedly a catch-all covariate, but theoretically it is possible that older adults could respond differently, for instance, to an employee asking for an extension because he slept in compared to younger adults. I would like to control for that unaccounted-for error variation. 

Gender - also a catch-all covariate. It is possible, again, that male respondents may evaluate each message differently than female or non-binary respondents, perhaps because of the gender of the message source (George is identifed as a man).

Need for cognition - respondents higher in need for cognition may demonstrate larger argument-quality effects (Luttrell, Petty & Xu, 2017), so I'd like to control for this individual difference.

Trait empathy - participants who find it easier to empathize with others in general may experience a ceiling effect, where fatigue can't make them empathize any more than they typically do. I would like to control for trait empathy so any empathy effects are specific to fatigue rather than this individual difference. 

Any manipulation checks that fail would indicate that the strong argument is seen by participants as, potentially, more difficult to understand (or hard to follow or complex) than the weak argument. In this case, any differences in persuasion might be due to argument difficulty rather than argument quality.

question1c.value:
All predictor variables (excepting state empathy) and covariates are identical to the first prediction. 

The outcome variable in this case, though, will be message involvement. After reverse-scoring the five reverse-coded questions, I will assess the reliability of the 10 Personal Involvement Inventory items and if sufficient, I will calculate a composite score by averaging them together.

question2c.value:
A between-subjects ANCOVA will be conducted predicting message involvement from argument quality (1 = strong, -1 = weak), current fatigue, fatigue relevance (-1 = irrelevant, 1 = relevant), and all interactions controlling for current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks that failed. 95% confidence intervals and effect sizes (partial eta-squared) for regression coefficients will also be calculated. 

The analysis will be run a second time without the covariates.

If the predicted current fatigue x message relevance interaction predicting message involvement is significant (or close to), the following simple effects analyses will be conducted:

1. The simple effect of current fatigue in the fatigue-relevant condition - I expect that as fatigue increases, message involvement will increase. 

2. The simple effect of current fatigue in the fatigue-irrelevant condition - I expect that as fatigue increases, message involvement will decrease.

question3c.value:
Argument quality and fatigue relevance are true, manipulated IVs.

Current fatigue is a non-manipulated, continuous predictor variable. 

Fatigue relevance is a potential moderator of the interaction between argument quality and current fatigue (in which current fatigue moderates argument quality effects). 

Message involvement is the primary dependent measure. 

Current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks re: argument difficulty that fail are covariates.

question4c.value:
Current mood - mood may relate to differences motivation to attend to and process persuasive communications (see Bohner, Crow, Erb & Schwarz, 1992; Mitchell, 2000)

Age - this is admittedly a catch-all covariate, but theoretically it is possible that older adults might be more or less involved with a remote employee asking for an extension compared to younger adults. 

Gender - also a catch-all covariate. It is possible that male respondents may find a message from a male employee more involving than would female or non-binary respondents.

Need for cognition - I plan to include this to keep the analyses across the three predictions as similar as possible; but perhaps respondents higher in need for cognition will find it easier to be involved in any message. 

Trait empathy - participants who find it easier to empathize with others in general may experience a ceiling effect in involvement, where fatigue can't boost involvement any more. 

Any manipulation checks that fail would indicate that the strong argument is seen by participants as, potentially, more difficult to understand (or hard to follow or complex) than the weak argument. In this case, any differences in involvement might be due to argument difficulty differences.

question1c.value:
All predictor variables (excepting state empathy) and covariates are identical to the first prediction. 

The outcome variable in this case, though, will be state empathy toward the writer of the message. The 11 items from the Shen (2010) empathy scale will be averaged together, assuming sufficient internal consistency.

question2c.value:
A between-subjects ANCOVA will be conducted predicting state empathy from argument quality (1 = strong, -1 = weak), current fatigue, fatigue relevance (-1 = irrelevant, 1 = relevant), and all interactions controlling for current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks that failed. 95% confidence intervals and effect sizes (partial eta-squared) for regression coefficients will also be calculated. 

The analysis will be run a second time without the covariates.

If the predicted current fatigue x message relevance interaction predicting state empathy is significant (or close to), the following simple effects analyses will be conducted:

1. The simple effect of current fatigue in the fatigue-relevant condition: I predict state empathy will increase as current fatigue increases regardless of argument quality. 

2. The simple effect of current fatigue in the fatigue-irrelevant condition: I predict state empathy will do nothing as current fatigue increases.

question3c.value:
Argument quality and fatigue relevance are true, manipulated IVs.

Current fatigue is a non-manipulated, continuous predictor variable. 

Fatigue relevance is a potential moderator of the interaction between argument quality and current fatigue (in which current fatigue moderates argument quality effects). 

State empathy is the primary dependent measure. 

Current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks re: argument difficulty that fail are covariates.

question4c.value:
Current mood - mood may relate to differences in empathy (see Nezlek et al., 2001; Cao et al., 2017)

Age - this is admittedly a catch-all covariate, but theoretically it is possible that older adults might empathize differently with a remote employee asking for an extension compared to younger adults. 

Gender - also a catch-all covariate. It is possible, that male respondents may find it easier to empathize with a male employee compared to female or non-binary respondents. 

Need for cognition - I don't know of any research connecting NFC with state empathy, but perhaps those higher in NFC may be more likely to pay attention to details in the message, notice that the employee is overtired, and empathize because of that advantage in knowledge.

Trait empathy - participants who find it easier to empathize with others in general may experience a ceiling effect, where fatigue can't make them empathize any more than they typically do. I would like to control for trait empathy so any empathy effects are specific to fatigue rather than this individual difference. 

Any manipulation checks that fail would indicate that the strong argument is seen by participants as, potentially, more difficult to understand (or hard to follow or complex) than the weak argument. In this case, any differences in empathy might be due to argument difficulty differences.

registration_responses.additionalComments: I plan to start data analysis upon pre-registration.

1. Hot-cold empathy gap account (e.g., Nordgren, van der Pligt, and van Harreveld, 2007; Loewenstein, 2005): If fatigue leads to a match between the visceral states of participants and the message source, then fatigued participants should be more persuaded by a fatigue-relevant message (and empathize more with its source & be more involved with the message), regardless of argument quality. registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
1. Argument quality (weak vs. strong argument)
a. Between-participant
b. orthogonal

2. Fatigue relevance of the message (low vs. high)
a. Between-participant
b. orthogonal

3. Fatigue (non-manipulated continuous, measured predictor variable; measured with 4 items [fatigued, tired, sleepy, drowsy] embedded in a distractor list)
a. between-participant
b. orthogonal
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
1. Message evaluation/persuasion (5 9-point semantic differentials from Petty et al., 1977)

2. State empathy toward message source (11 items from 12-item Shen empathy scale (2010); 7-point responses from "Not at all" to "Completely" - 1 item left out due to clerical error ("I can understand what the character was going through in the message")

3. Message involvement (10 items from the Personal Involvement Inventory [Zaichkowsky, 1994])
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b:
1. Manipulation check - participant rating of argument quality - this should differ between the strong and weak argument conditions

2. Manipulation check - participant rating of how difficult the argument was to understand, how hard it was to follow, and the extent to which it had a complex structure. These should not differ between the strong and weak argument conditions, and if they do, they should be controlled for. 

3. Current mood (3 items, 7-point response from "very bad-very good," "very sad - very happy," and "very unpleasant - very pleasant." 

4. Need for Cognition (Petty, Cacioppo & Kao's [1984] version) will be used as a covariate since the measure relates to persuasion. 

5. Trait empathy (Davis' [1980) Interpersonal Reactivity Index). This will be used as a covariate to control for individual differences in general ability/tendency to empathize with others.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question6c: I plan to use Benjamini & Hochberg's (2000) adaptive procedure to control the false discovery rate across the three ANCOVAs while keeping power as high as possible.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question7c:
In cases where participants do not complete an entire scale, that variable will not be included for that individual, meaning that if that variable is included in an analysis, that participant will not be included. 

If the participant completes the majority of questions in a given scale, their average on the completed questions will stand for their composite score.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question8c:
For all previously-validated scales, all items will be included. 

For the current fatigue measure, since I have used only the four fatigue-sleepy-tired-drowsy items in past work, I will do so again here.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question9c: None other than averaging for composite scores.
registration_responses.recommended-methods.procedure.question9b: The data has already been collected.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Participants were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: strong, fatigue-relevant argument, strong, fatigue-irrelevant argument, weak, fatigue-relevant argument, and weak, fatigue-irrelevant argument. All participants first read a persuasive message. In the fatigue-relevant condition, participants were instructed to read an email from an overtired employee named George asking his boss explaining why he missed a project deadline and requesting an extension. In the fatigue-irrelevant condition, participants were instructed to read a communication regarding a new comprehensive exam policy at a large state university in the U.S.. The fatigue-relevant weak and strong arguments had been piloted for argument quality in prior work. The fatigue-irrelevant arguments were adapted to match the length of the other arguments in the study from Luttrell et al., 2017.

Following this, all participants completed the primary dependent measures of persuasion, empathy and involvement. The question order for each of the following sections was randomized. The persuasion measure consisted of five 9-point semantic differentials assessing participants' evaluation of the message (example: "To what extent do you think the communication made its point effectively?" from "not at all" to "completely;" from Petty et al., 1977). They then completed 11 items from the 12-item Shen (2010) empathy scale using seven response options (example: "I experienced the same emotions as the writer did when reading the article" from "Not at all" to "completely"). The items used George as a referent in the fatigue-relevant condition and 'the writer' as a referent in the fatigue-irrelevant condition. Participant involvement in the message was assessed with the 10-item Personal Involvement Inventory (Zaichkowsky, 1994) with the referent adapted depending on the fatigue relevance condition. While all participants responded to the 10 items using 7-point semantic differentials (e.g., "To me, X is unimportant-important, boring-interesting, etc."), the referent (X) was "George's emailed request" for those in the fatigue-relevant condition and "the article" in the fatigue-irrelevant condition. 

Following the main dependent measures, participants responded to manipulation checks on the argument quality manipulation. The first of these four items assessed their rating of the quality of the arguments using 11 options from "Not very good arguments" to "Very good arguments." The other three manipulation checks measured the difficulty of the arguments, how hard they were to follow, and the extent to which they had a complex structure, each on an 8-point response scale from "Not at all" to "Extremely."

In the next section of the survey, participants indicated the extent to which a series of 24 terms  applied to them at that moment. Most of these terms were distractor items, but seven items related to current fatigue: fatigued, tired, sleepy, drowsy, energetic, aware, and awake. 

The next question was an attention check in which participants were instructed not to respond with their favorite color but with "white", with the question itself asking what their favorite color was. 

Participants then completed the 18-item Need for Cognition scale (Petty, Cacioppo & Kao, 1984) and the 28-item Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davis, 1980). They provided their gender, age, and ethnicity, reported how seriously they took the study using five response options from "I honestly blew through the questions and did not pay attention to the instructions" to "I took my time and answered thoughtfully." They were given a text box to enter any comments regarding typos or unclear instructions and read debriefing information.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
Predictor variables:

Argument quality condition will be coded as weak = -1 and strong = +1. 

Current fatigue will be assessed with four of the seven current fatigue terms (fatigued, tired, sleepy, drowsy). Previous work with this measure has suggested that these four tend to have the highest internal consistency. The internal consistency will be assessed using Cronbach's alpha, and given sufficient reliability they will be averaged together to create a current fatigue composite score. 

Fatigue relevance of the message will be coded as -1 = fatigue irrelevant and +1 = fatigue relevant. 

Outcome variables:

Persuasion: The internal consistency of the five message-evaluation items will be assessed using Cronbach's alpha. Given sufficient reliability, they will be averaged together to create a persuasion composite score. 

Covariates: If the manipulation checks on argument difficulty, how hard it was to follow, and the complexity of its structure fail (i.e., they differ between the strong and weak argument conditions), the relevant manipulation checks will be controlled for in the analysis. The three current mood items will be checked for reliability using Cronbach's alpha and averaged together to create a current mood composite. The same reliability check + compositing process will be completed for Need for Cognition (18 items) and Trait Empathy (using the 26 items from Davis' Interpersonal Reactivity Index). Gender will be coded as -1 = male, 0 = non-binary, and +1 = female. Age will be used as a quantitative continuous variable.

A between-subjects ANCOVA will be conducted predicting persuasion from argument quality (1 = strong, -1 = weak), current fatigue, fatigue relevance (-1 = irrelevant, 1 = relevant), and all interactions controlling for current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks that failed. 95% confidence intervals and effect sizes (partial eta-squared) for regression coefficients will also be calculated. 

The analysis will be run a second time without the covariates.

If the predicted argument quality x current fatigue x message relevance interaction predicting persuasion is significant (or close to), the following simple effects analyses will be conducted:

1. A simple 2-way argument quality x current fatigue interaction when the message is fatigue relevant - I predict no interaction, but that persuasion will increase as current fatigue increases regardless of argument quality. 

2. A simple 2-way argument quality x current fatigue interaction when the message is not fatigue relevant - I predict an interaction such that participants higher in fatigue will display a smaller argument quality effect than participants lower in fatigue. 

If significant, the simple effect of current fatigue when arguments are weak will be tested as well as the simple effect of current fatigue when arguments are strong.

Argument quality and fatigue relevance are true, manipulated IVs.

Current fatigue is a non-manipulated, continuous predictor variable. 

Fatigue relevance is seen as a moderator of the interaction between argument quality and current fatigue (in which current fatigue moderates argument quality effects). 

Persuasion is the primary dependent measure. 

Current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks re: argument difficulty that fail are covariates.

Current mood - since mood can impact persuasion (see Bless et al., 1990), it will be controlled for. 

Age - this is admittedly a catch-all covariate, but theoretically it is possible that older adults could respond differently, for instance, to an employee asking for an extension because he slept in compared to younger adults. I would like to control for that unaccounted-for error variation. 

Gender - also a catch-all covariate. It is possible, again, that male respondents may evaluate each message differently than female or non-binary respondents, perhaps because of the gender of the message source (George is identifed as a man).

Need for cognition - respondents higher in need for cognition may demonstrate larger argument-quality effects (Luttrell, Petty & Xu, 2017), so I'd like to control for this individual difference.

Trait empathy - participants who find it easier to empathize with others in general may experience a ceiling effect, where fatigue can't make them empathize any more than they typically do. I would like to control for trait empathy so any empathy effects are specific to fatigue rather than this individual difference. 

Any manipulation checks that fail would indicate that the strong argument is seen by participants as, potentially, more difficult to understand (or hard to follow or complex) than the weak argument. In this case, any differences in persuasion might be due to argument difficulty rather than argument quality.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi:
All predictor variables (excepting state empathy) and covariates are identical to the first prediction. 

The outcome variable in this case, though, will be message involvement. After reverse-scoring the five reverse-coded questions, I will assess the reliability of the 10 Personal Involvement Inventory items and if sufficient, I will calculate a composite score by averaging them together.

A between-subjects ANCOVA will be conducted predicting message involvement from argument quality (1 = strong, -1 = weak), current fatigue, fatigue relevance (-1 = irrelevant, 1 = relevant), and all interactions controlling for current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks that failed. 95% confidence intervals and effect sizes (partial eta-squared) for regression coefficients will also be calculated. 

The analysis will be run a second time without the covariates.

If the predicted current fatigue x message relevance interaction predicting message involvement is significant (or close to), the following simple effects analyses will be conducted:

1. The simple effect of current fatigue in the fatigue-relevant condition - I expect that as fatigue increases, message involvement will increase. 

2. The simple effect of current fatigue in the fatigue-irrelevant condition - I expect that as fatigue increases, message involvement will decrease.

Argument quality and fatigue relevance are true, manipulated IVs.

Current fatigue is a non-manipulated, continuous predictor variable. 

Fatigue relevance is a potential moderator of the interaction between argument quality and current fatigue (in which current fatigue moderates argument quality effects). 

Message involvement is the primary dependent measure. 

Current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks re: argument difficulty that fail are covariates.

Current mood - mood may relate to differences motivation to attend to and process persuasive communications (see Bohner, Crow, Erb & Schwarz, 1992; Mitchell, 2000)

Age - this is admittedly a catch-all covariate, but theoretically it is possible that older adults might be more or less involved with a remote employee asking for an extension compared to younger adults. 

Gender - also a catch-all covariate. It is possible that male respondents may find a message from a male employee more involving than would female or non-binary respondents.

Need for cognition - I plan to include this to keep the analyses across the three predictions as similar as possible; but perhaps respondents higher in need for cognition will find it easier to be involved in any message. 

Trait empathy - participants who find it easier to empathize with others in general may experience a ceiling effect in involvement, where fatigue can't boost involvement any more. 

Any manipulation checks that fail would indicate that the strong argument is seen by participants as, potentially, more difficult to understand (or hard to follow or complex) than the weak argument. In this case, any differences in involvement might be due to argument difficulty differences.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: These data have already been collected in April 2019.
All participants were recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk and completed the experiment on SurveyMonkey. They were paid $1.25 for 15 minutes of their time.

While a formal power analysis was not conducted, prior studies I've run in this area suggested that a sample size of 125 would be sufficient to pick up on a small effect size with a power criterion of 80%, given two conditions and five covariates. With this more complicated, 4-condition study, I was limited by budget concerns to collecting only 100 participants per each of the 4 conditions, so the sample size very likely is too small for 80% power.
Budget constraints limited me to collecting 100 participants per each of the 4 conditions.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques:
All predictor variables (excepting state empathy) and covariates are identical to the first prediction. 

The outcome variable in this case, though, will be state empathy toward the writer of the message. The 11 items from the Shen (2010) empathy scale will be averaged together, assuming sufficient internal consistency.

A between-subjects ANCOVA will be conducted predicting state empathy from argument quality (1 = strong, -1 = weak), current fatigue, fatigue relevance (-1 = irrelevant, 1 = relevant), and all interactions controlling for current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks that failed. 95% confidence intervals and effect sizes (partial eta-squared) for regression coefficients will also be calculated. 

The analysis will be run a second time without the covariates.

If the predicted current fatigue x message relevance interaction predicting state empathy is significant (or close to), the following simple effects analyses will be conducted:

1. The simple effect of current fatigue in the fatigue-relevant condition: I predict state empathy will increase as current fatigue increases regardless of argument quality. 

2. The simple effect of current fatigue in the fatigue-irrelevant condition: I predict state empathy will do nothing as current fatigue increases.

Argument quality and fatigue relevance are true, manipulated IVs.

Current fatigue is a non-manipulated, continuous predictor variable. 

Fatigue relevance is a potential moderator of the interaction between argument quality and current fatigue (in which current fatigue moderates argument quality effects). 

State empathy is the primary dependent measure. 

Current mood, age, gender, need for cognition, trait empathy and any manipulation checks re: argument difficulty that fail are covariates.

Current mood - mood may relate to differences in empathy (see Nezlek et al., 2001; Cao et al., 2017)

Age - this is admittedly a catch-all covariate, but theoretically it is possible that older adults might empathize differently with a remote employee asking for an extension compared to younger adults. 

Gender - also a catch-all covariate. It is possible, that male respondents may find it easier to empathize with a male employee compared to female or non-binary respondents. 

Need for cognition - I don't know of any research connecting NFC with state empathy, but perhaps those higher in NFC may be more likely to pay attention to details in the message, notice that the employee is overtired, and empathize because of that advantage in knowledge.

Trait empathy - participants who find it easier to empathize with others in general may experience a ceiling effect, where fatigue can't make them empathize any more than they typically do. I would like to control for trait empathy so any empathy effects are specific to fatigue rather than this individual difference. 

Any manipulation checks that fail would indicate that the strong argument is seen by participants as, potentially, more difficult to understand (or hard to follow or complex) than the weak argument. In this case, any differences in empathy might be due to argument difficulty differences.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
I incorporated an attention-check question which will be used to exclude inattentive participants (or programs which aren't participants at all).

Toward the end of the study, participants also self-report their attention levels. Those who self-report that they "honestly blew through the questions and did not pay attention to the instructions" will be excluded. 

The dataset will also be inspected, and if it is obvious that an individual did not pay attention (that is, selected the same response for the entire study), they will be excluded. Edge cases (maybe they were attentive, maybe not) will be kept in the dataset.
